pillars.title: Reason to Begin
pillars.description: Why Are We in Business Together? Purpose & values - What was the original heartbeat behind this business?

questions.text: Why did we start—or why are we still here?
questions.description: What was the original heartbeat behind this business? What drove the initial decision to begin this venture?

questions.text: If your children or grandchildren asked, 'Why does our family own this business?'—what would you say?
questions.description: Think about the legacy and meaning you want to pass down. What story would you tell about the purpose of this business?

questions.text: What values must we never compromise, even when things get tough?
questions.description: Identify the core principles that define who you are as a family business. These are the non-negotiables that guide every decision.

pillars.title: Business Type
pillars.description: End Game Thinking - Ownership & future. Do I want us to keep this business for generations, or prepare to sell one day?

questions.text: Do I want us to keep this business for generations, or prepare to sell one day? Why?
questions.description: Consider your long-term vision for the business. Is this a legacy to preserve or an investment to eventually realize?

questions.text: What kind of role do I want—operator, owner, investor, supporter?
questions.description: Think about your desired level of involvement in the business. Are you hands-on, strategic oversight, or passive investment?

questions.text: Who should be allowed to own shares—and who shouldn't? Where do I draw the line, and why?
questions.description: Define the boundaries for ownership participation. Consider family members, employees, and external parties.

pillars.title: Expectations
pillars.description: The Three Circles & Beyond - Roles & responsibility. Where do I sit today—Family, Business, Ownership?

questions.text: Where do I sit today—Family, Business, Ownership? Am I clear about that?
questions.description: Identify your current roles in the three circles of family business. You may wear multiple hats—be specific about each.

questions.text: Do I believe we have a clear succession plan—or are we hoping things just work out?
questions.description: Assess the current state of succession planning. Be honest about whether you have a real plan or just hopes and assumptions.

questions.text: What do I expect from other family members—and what do I think they expect of me?
questions.description: Consider the mutual expectations within your family business. Include both explicit agreements and unspoken assumptions.

pillars.title: Extinction
pillars.description: What Could Go Wrong? Risk & resilience. What's the biggest threat to our family staying united in business?

questions.text: What's the biggest threat to our family staying united in business?
questions.description: Identify the primary risks that could fracture your family business relationships. Consider both business and family dynamics.

questions.text: Where are we strong—and where are we vulnerable—when it comes to people, money, skills, and relationships?
questions.description: Conduct an honest assessment of your family business strengths and weaknesses across all critical areas.

questions.text: Who makes the tough calls in our family business today?
questions.description: Identify the decision-making authority for difficult situations. Consider both formal structures and informal influence.

text: What's the biggest threat to our family staying united in business?
description: Identify the most significant risks that could divide your family or damage the business.

text: Where are we strong—and where are we vulnerable—when it comes to people, money, skills, and relationships?
description: Conduct an honest assessment of your family business's strengths and weaknesses.

text: Who makes the tough calls in our family business today? Is that clear—and is it working?
description: Evaluate your current decision-making structure and its effectiveness.
